narratives.question_text: Looking back on this course, what is your overall assessment of the course:  What are its strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might it be improved?
comments: Good course. This class is a good compliment to Epi 1 and 2 and goes more into depth on Epi measurement issues than any other class. Some of the guest lecturers were not very good and the primary professor tended to go off topic during class.
strengths - learn important concepts about measurement issues
Wonderful and interesting course! Very applicable content, especially for conducting our own studies and life after YSPH. I really liked the use of guest speakers and the presentations at the end!

this was a good course, in general. i think we could have gone more in depth in a lot of the measurement issues but the course provided a good overview of important things to consider when designing and evaluating epidemiological studies
good class - covers important aspects of epidemiology
great class.
No strengths. The same issues are sung over and over again. Makes the class uninteresting and difficult to go to class.

This was a great, multifaceted, experts forum of an epi-measurements class -- availing the students to some of the best that the Yale medical-research community has to offer in terms of epi measurements (eg, Dr Mayne, Dr Irwin, Dr Rothberg-Gould, Dr Illuzzi, Dr Lewis, Dr White, and Dr Ma).It really complemented the other coursework that many CDE first-years are taking or have taken, namely Epi II, Cancer Epi, and Psychosocial Epi.

The course covered many important measurement issues of common exposures, confounders, and outcomes that we are likely to encounter, and gave us experience in assessing the quality of measurement of these factors when reading published studies.
This course is very basic and should be required for first year Masters students. By the 2nd year, 95% of this course's content has been covered in other classes in EPH.

I think the midterm and final are helpful, but the homework assignments did not especially provide an added benefit. I also really enjoyed the group project, but I would extend the page limit to allow more discussion about measurement issues with the confounders and disease.

This class was very repetitive of what we learned in Epi I and Epi II, and most epi classes at YSPH. I don't believe that this course needs to be a course on its own but perhaps embedded into another course or taken as a half semester course.
useful but dry.
It was a requirement ;(

I think this should course should be taken as a culmination of the 2 year MPH experience (encourage students to take this as a second year) - this way, student will have already had the chance to become better at epi methods and can concentrate on the more difficult aspects of measurement. My suggestion is to make this a 1/2 semester, 2nd year course that is more concentrated and can be more challenging.
The course was great; one of my favorites this semester. I think it was partially because of Prof. Ma though--she really cares about her students and is not afraid to be frank with us.

This is an excellent course, and one that is a complement to Epidemiology I and II. The course covers measurement issues related to a range of health-related variables and is challenging and interesting in that it focuses on critical thinking and analysis. The course is well organized and makes good use of several guest lecturers.

The class teaches students how to criticize the methodology of studies so as to encourage higher-quality in academic epidemiology. I think it teaches this sufficiently, though is slightly repetitive in its discussion of themes. Other than that, I gained a lot from the course.

The main strength of this course is that it gives you the ability to rigorously critique an epidemiological study. Dr. Ma gives you the framework to analyze how measurement occurs, and what biases may be inherent to different techniques. I enjoyed the lectures and found Dr. Ma to be an excellent professor. The one weakness I found in this course, however, is that there just didn't seem to be enough material to fill an entire semester. By the end of the term, this course felt very repetitive.

This is an excellent overview course about the potential issues in measurement that can arise in chronic disease epidemiology. It provides a broad survey of various exposures (and some outcomes), providing insight into the reasons for various measurement issues and how to avoid them (or at least, take them into account). Dr. Ma does an excellent job of combining her own lectures with a sprinkling of other experts to provide a balanced and well taught course.
GOOD
This course is intersteing and helpful

narratives.question_text: Please evaluate the instructor of this course. What are the instructor's strengths and weaknesses, and in what ways might his or her teaching be improved?
comments: Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  strengths - good lectures, good sense of humor

Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  Wonderful teacher!! Very knowledgeable, helpful, and interesting! Good sense of humor and very fair! I really enjoyed her teaching style although I like the supplementation by guest lectures.
Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  professor was interesting, easy to understand, presented the information in a reasonable fashion. additionally, she was easy to talk to and always answered out questions
Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  good instructor

Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  The professor told many stories relating her personal career experience with the subject material. This was an excellent method of teaching and allowed the students to get a feel for the "real life" experience.
Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  Great
Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  is very knowledgeable and sensitive to students. She is an instructor that really cares about how students are doing.

Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  Professor Ma is outstanding in every regard.She has great respect for the teaching profession and for the students, while being a distinguished researcher herself (which we learn on our own, she is too unassuming to tell us).She always made herself available to students after and out of class to address questions matter-of-factly and thoughtfully. She doesn't avoid complexity, and she is brilliant and humble enough to welcome divergent opinions for the greater good in learning and research.Hers was a great, multifaceted, experts forum of a measurement class.Bravo!

Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  Dr. Ma had well-prepared presentations and was an interesting lecturer. She was extremely helpful, and even offered to provided advice in the future if we ran into issues, even after graduation.
Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  Dr. Ma means well but she dumbed down a lot of the information to an oversimplified level.

Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  Dr. Ma definitely seems to care about students, and provides helpful and encouraging feedback. I think she also brought some relevant life experiences into the course instruction, making the class a bit more interesting and relevant. I also liked that she pulled in outside speakers who are experts in specific fields.
Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  Dr. Ma is very knowledgable about the topics covered and was very helpful during office hours.
Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  she knows her stuff well.
Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  Dr. Ma is wonderful - she is a very kind and sharp professor, who is quick to catch on to student misunderstandings. She is a bit dry as a lecturer.

Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  Prof. Ma did a fabulous job with the lectures and guests that came to speak with us. She was really flexible even during class time to answer our questions and was very frank with us. I liked that the class was very open. I actually really enjoyed the presentations from the students as well--I am under the assumption that some of those are their actual research projects (really exciting to see all that going on with fellow students behind the scenes!). It really brings together how we can apply what we learn in the classroom to applications out, and that's always important.Prof. Ma to be an extremely good/understanding/yet still solid instructor. Most students I talked to really liked/respect/admire her and her work, and I think that builds an atmosphere where it is really conducive to learning.

Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  I found Dr. Ma to be a wonderful instructor who was willing to share her own thoughts and feelings about any areas pertaining to conducting epidemiological research without telling students how they should think about certain issues which was refreshing. I also appreciated that she took class time to go over the main take home points from assignments so that students could walk away with these messages and make connections to epidemiology and biostatistics even if they had not picked up on them the first time through.

Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  Professor Ma is a clear and interesting lecturer who is extremely knowledgeable about the subject matter. I appreciated that she added personal anecdotes to her lectures and took an interest in the students.

Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  Dr. Ma is a very good lecturer, and manages to make a sometimes less-than-interesting topic a highly-relevant one. Her lectures were well-organized, and her guest lectures were often very enjoyable.
Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  Excellent. Very knowledgeable, kind, approachable, and funny! A dedicated and patient teacher.
Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  Dr. Ma is a skilled instructor and always made herself available to her students. She also made us feel like her colleagues, which was much appreciated!
Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  Dr. Ma was funny, engaging, and very nice. Also, she as very knowledgable about the subject matter.
Instructor: Xiaomei Ma  Dr. Ma is a great instructor

Unjali Gujral was a very good TA. She was very helpful in answering questions and approachable.
I hardly see the TA around. I only knew who she is towards the end of the class.
Unjali was very organized and thoughtful in her grading of our assignments.
She was nice; though we didn't really have too much interaction with her.
Unjali did a nice job.
Unjali was a fantastic TA, quick to respond to any questions and very helpful.
I did not engage Unjali very often during the course. The few times I did, she was very responsive.

narratives.question_text: How would you summarize this course for a fellow student? Would you recommend it to another student? Why or why not?
comments: good course for all CDE students and anyone thinking of conducting research in the future
Definitely would recommend it; very useful and pertinent! I took it and was not even required to!
Overall, for a required course, this class was interesting and not overly demanding. i learned a good deal without having to kill myself over the material.
I would recommend this class
Great course. There is overlap between this class and other epi classes, so it is helpful for anyone who wants to strengthen their understanding of epi research.
Dont take it if you dont have to.
Read above. :)

This class teaches many important things about difficulties and methods of assessing many common exposures, outcomes, and confounders. Definitely an important class if you are planning to work with chronic diseases in the future.
This course is very basic measurement issues. It is a broad overview but inappropriate and redundant for 2nd year students.
I would definitely recommend this course, preferably before doing the thesis. It provides a useful way to think about study design and different issues that may come up in research.

This course was very repetitive of what we learned in other courses. I would recommend this course if you have had little exposure to epidemiology, but otherwise, this course could be shorten or embedded into another required class.
its usefulness is only felt years later.
A general overview of epi concepts with focus on measurement of exposure and disease. A low stress class that has room for improvement.

You learn a lot from this course without realizing it; I really enjoyed the format and the variety of topics covered. The class load is really manageable and I found Prof. Ma to be an extremely good/understanding/yet still solid instructor. Most students I talked to really liked/respect/admire her and her work.
I would strongly recommend this course to students with an interest in epidemiology.
This is a good class if you are interested in learning how to critique studies and assess their quality. It's very practical and useful for those interested in applied epidemiology.
As a second year it was a lot f repeat information from other required classes. I think it would be more helpful to take it during the first year of the program.

This class will give you a solid background in critiquing epidemiological studies. I feel like I had some ability to critique papers beforehand, but this course provided a solid framework to use in the future. Dr. Ma is an excellent teacher, though individual lectures can sometimes feel dry and repetitive. Much of what you learn is covered in other courses, so the main strength is learning how to apply it towards your critiques. I recommend the course, but don't expect it to be more than it is.

This is an excellent overview course about the potential issues in measurement that can arise in chronic disease epidemiology. It provides a broad survey of various exposures (and some outcomes), providing insight into the reasons for various measurement issues and how to avoid them (or at least, take them into account). Dr. Ma does an excellent job of combining her own lectures with a sprinkling of other experts to provide a balanced and well taught course.
Required course. I would still recommend it, though, even to someone who wasn't CDE.
GOOD COURSE BUT HAS TO BE MORE ORGANIZED
